comments.commentBody: Like Hodding Carter III said: "It's a long haul...Keep sounding the bugle." We can vote, and must do so, but voting's not enough.  We have to be in the streets, in very large numbers, as often as possible.  And we need to not be afraid of looking foolish, and we need to grow a thick skin in the face of nasty, despicable comments from GOP elected officials (see the article).  The 99%, the rational, anyone concerned about preserving a basic safety net, preserving democracy, and preserving a climate that is amenable to human civilization, has to stand their ground for big, big changes.  My deepest gratitude goes to all the Moral Monday participants.

Slowriter59, you misunderstood the argument by incorporating future economic benefits into an activity that has no economic benefit in and of itself.  The argument is that the inherent economic benefit of an activity is an inadequate, indeed severely inadequate, measure of its value -- both economic and noneconomic value.

Prof. K oversimplifies, too, not selfishly as does L, but economistically.  If prosperity is synonymous with production, then production is that which is measured in dollars or some other economic unit.  I disagree with that; it is fundamentally wrong (i.e., inadequate).  Scientific production is not economic.  It is, however, essential for the later existence of technological invention and consequent economic production.  For instance, the reported discovery of gravitational waves from the Big Bang is a kind of production that reaps no economic rewards and has no effect on prosperity.  Possibly, it will lead to understanding of gravity waves that will yield faster-than-light travel (just supposing!) that will have enormous economic productivity, but the discovery in itself has zero economic value.  For such reasons I reject the assumption that "prosperity" is the measure of value (in the broad sense, not the technical economic sense).

I agree with Andersramsay on the utter ineptitude of the MTA. ...and their dumb countdown clocks. I know many folks like the clocks, but these are probably the same people who like to stare at their phones 24/7. The fact of the matter is, these countdown clocks really don’t impact most people’s commutes. Unless you have the luxury of taking a different subway line to your destination, and that subway line is within that same station, you are going to have to WAIT for your train, whether that little countdown clock tells you the train is coming in 2 minutes, or 20 minutes.

Also, indeed some of those clocks are downright confusing. I remember I (a local person) was waiting at a platform that I think was for both the 2 and 3 trains. The display said something like ‘1 – Uptown train in 3 minutes.’ The next line said ‘2 – Uptown train in 6 minutes’. Something on that idea… All I remember thinking was ‘is 1 the number of the train line? Or do they mean the next train, which they refer to as train # 1’? If I a local couldn’t understand the clock, how would a tourist?

And then there are the MTA’s service advisory change notices. So much info your eyes glaze over. Those poor tourists!

The MTA is just run by a bunch of unintelligent cronies. It needs a much higher level of professional, educated employees.

Many others, and certainly those of us who are natives, remember better days (for some things--some things are worse) so know these aren't fundamental attributes of the city and want to see them changed.  And, indeed, one sees progress from time to time only because of those who aren't complacent.  To use your words, the people New York "just isn't for" are the ones who don't care enough about it to want to see it continuously improve.

@Larry L : There is quite a lot that can be done technically to reduce energy use but it may not be an economic priority for many Americans. Here in coastal California, natural gas and electricity is my smallest bill. It is less than telecommunications, less than water & sewage, and much less than the home owners association fees. Even though California's commitment to renewables has driven up electricity prices here, energy remains very affordable for many.

When looking at remodeling projects, things that a buyer will immediately see, like new flooring and fresh paint, have taken precedence for me over energy efficiency things like new windows. I probably won't be staying in this house long enough for most energy efficiency upgrades to pay off, and I doubt that a buyer will pay a premium for them on resale.

@lou and rusty: I've heard claims that the US could increase natural gas output by 50% and sustain it for decades. Building the infrastructure to export LNG will take years. However, if the Kremlin's European customers started to seriously consider US LNG because they no longer felt comfortable buying from Russia then I think that would make an impression with the Russians.

Russia seems to have two vulnerabilities. One is that the US is now in a position to export gas to Europe. Thanks to the shale gas revolution, America has plenty of gas to sell. If Europe is willing to pay a little more, they can build liquefied natural gas (LNG) plants in the US and eliminate their dependence on Russia. The Europeans have to decide if the lower price of Russian pipeline gas is worth the political hassle.

The second vulnerability is that the Russia runs a large trade surplus with the US. We import $2.40 worth of Russian goods for every $1 we export. This means that US workers would benefit if US-Russia trade came to a standstill. Russia gets away with this because US economic policy is in the hands of pro-globalization types. It is time to balance US-Russia trade with tariffs, and in the process create an example for China, Germany and Japan of what can happen to a country who runs chronic trade surpluses with America. If Russia retaliates against US exports, then we will balance the trade at zero.
I am sure China will gladly loan more to both us and Russia, to finance our war mongering...

The US has a huge opportunity to move from the back seat to the drivers seat of the global energy bus, replacing some truly undesirable oligarchs in Russia, the Middle East, Venezuela and elsewhere.

We currently consume about twice the MPG as the global auto fleet. We have less rail, and virtually no high speed rail, compared to other major economies. Our home heating is far less efficient than the rest of the planet.

This might appear to be a big problem but the good news is that the technology already is in use almost everywhere else. That's why President Obama was able to gain agreement with the Big Three automakers to double CAFE standards by 2025. Other conversions are needed as well, in mass transit, home heating and lighting.

The truth is that the US could cut fossil fuel energy consumption dramatically without lifestyle tradeoffs with current technology.

But if we can't even figure out how to replace 100 watt light bulbs with halogen 72 watt bulbs (not CFLs) that produce the same light output and quality without a huge political backlash, I believe the energy oligarchs will be driving the bus for the foreseeable future.
